metadata.titleEn: A 1 km daily soil moisture dataset over China based on in-situ measurement (2000-2022)
metadata.description: This study provides China 1 km high quality of the Soil Moisture data set - SMCI1.0 (Soil Moisture of China by the in situ data, version 1.0), SMCI1.0 is consists of 2000-2022, scale, to 10 cm interval layer depth (10-100 cm) high space-time resolution of Soil Moisture, the data unit is 0.001 m after/m after.The missing value is -999 The data set is provided by the China Meteorological Administration 1648 sites observed 10 layer Soil moisture as a benchmark, using forced ERA5_Land meteorological data, the leaf area index (LAI), land cover types (Landtypes), terrain (DEM) and Soil characteristics, Soil properties) as a covariate, obtained by way of machine learning.This study conducted two experiments to validate the precision of the SMCI1.0, time scales: ubRMSE 0.041 0.052, R 0.883 0.919;Spatial scales: ubRMSE 0.045 0.051, R 0.866 0.893.Since SMCI1.0 is based on the field observations of soil moisture, it can serve as effective supplement of existing based on model and satellite data sets.Products can be used for the data of hydrology, meteorology, ecology analysis and modeling, especially in the need to high quality, high resolution on the application of soil moisture is crucial.About the reference of data set and a detailed description, please read the documentation.For ease of use, this study provides two different resolution version: 30 seconds (~ 1 km) and 0.1 (~ 9 km).
metadata.instructions:
File name: SMCI1.0 in stored in NetCDF (.nc) format, the file name is "SMCI"_ sskm_ yyyy_ ddcm.nc ", where ss stands for SMCI1.0's spatial resolution (1 or 9), yyyy stands for year, dd stands for the depth.
Data reading method: here are many freely available softwares or programming language such as python ,NCL, Panoply for manipulating or displaying NetCDF Data.

background: Soil moisture (SM) plays a key role in land–atmosphere interactions through its strong impacts on the water and carbon cycle. The status of SM is closely related to climate and weather conditions. The high-quality SM data with a fine spatial–temporal scale can be valued as indispensable tools for observing extreme weather events, e.g., droughts, floods, and carbon cycle modeling. Further, SM is also identified as an important component of the Essential Climate Variables by the Global Observing System for Climate. However, high-quality SM data acquisition is a challenging task due to the complicated spatiotemporal variations of the SM. Such spatiotemporal variations of SM are usually affected by the inherent heterogeneity of soils, land cover, and weather. At present, the methods for SM data estimation can be divided into five categories: in situ observations, satellite observations, offline land surface model simulations, Earth system model simulations, and reanalysis products. For in situ SM observations, SM data are usually measured by the probe measurement method, in which as direct observations this method usually leads to lower errors than satellite observations, land surface model simulations, Earth system model simulations, and reanalysis products. Although a large number of stations are distributed all over the world, there are still many regions with no in situ SM observations due to financial constraints, and field stations are too sparse to capture adequate spatial coverage. For satellite observations, SM data are mainly retrieved by microwave radiometers on satellites, which can provide the global SM data with uniform distributions, but for the microwave-radiometer-measured SM data from the near surface, only the top-layer SM can be retrieved and the data gaps exist in regions with dense vegetation and snow-covered or frozen soils. The SM data of the offline land surface model and Earth system model simulations span multiple soil layers and have a seamless spatial distribution, but they both have uncertain and different forcing factors due to the spatial sub-grid heterogeneity of soil properties and vegetation, thus leading to large differences from in situ SM observations. Reanalysis products can also provide SM data with good temporal variations by assimilating observations into land surface models or Earth system models. They can also provide SM data at deeper soil depth than satellite observations, but reanalysis products usually lead to higher disagreement with in situ SM observations when the assimilated meteorological variables are biased. In brief, the characteristic strong points and shortcomings both coexist in each type of SM product.
research objective: Hence, we are eager to develop the high-quality SM product which comprehensively has a high-resolution seamless spatial distribution, long time periods, and low errors from the above SM products.
challenges: However, the high errors of soil moisture are often located in the North China Monsoon Region.
methods: Here, we present a 1 km resolution long-term dataset of soil moisture derived through machine learning trained by the in situ measurements of 1789 stations over China, named SMCI1.0 (Soil Moisture of China by in situ data, version 1.0). Random forest is used as a robust machine learning approach to predict soil moisture using ERA5-Land time series, leaf area index, land cover type, topography and soil properties as predictors. Using in situ soil moisture as the benchmark, two independent experiments were conducted to evaluate the estimation accuracy of SMCI1.0: year-to-year and station-to-station experiments.
dataset: SMCI1.0 provides 10-layer soil moisture with 10 cm intervals up to 100 cm deep at daily resolution over the period 2000–2020.
findings: SMCI1.0 generally has advantages over other gridded soil moisture products, including ERA5-Land, SMAP-L4, and SoMo.ml. Overall, the highly accurate estimations of both the year-to-year and station-to-station experiments ensure the applicability of SMCI1.0 to study the spatial–temporal patterns. As SMCI1.0 is based on in situ data, it can be a useful complement to existing model-based and satellite-based soil moisture datasets for various hydrological, meteorological, and ecological analyses and models.

This dataset utilizes in situ measurements combined with machine learning predictions to achieve high accuracy and seamless spatial distribution.

Definition.Question: What are the main methods for soil moisture data estimation in terms of data collection techniques?
Definition.Answer: The methods for soil moisture data estimation can be divided into five categories: in situ observations, satellite observations, offline land surface model simulations, Earth system model simulations, and reanalysis products.

Definition.Question: What is the significance of in situ observations when collecting soil moisture data?
Definition.Answer: For in situ soil moisture observations, data are usually measured by the probe measurement method, which as direct observations usually leads to lower errors than other methods such as satellite observations, model simulations, and reanalysis products.

Definition.Question: How does machine learning contribute to the development of high-resolution soil moisture datasets?
Definition.Answer: Machine learning, specifically random forest, is used as a robust approach to predict soil moisture by training with in situ measurements and using various predictors such as ERA5-Land time series, leaf area index, land cover type, topography, and soil properties.

Comparison.Question: What are the similarities and differences in the spatial resolution and temporal coverage between offline land surface model simulations and Earth system model simulations for soil moisture data?
Comparison.Answer: Both offline land surface model simulations and Earth system model simulations span multiple soil layers and provide seamless spatial distribution of soil moisture data. However, they have uncertain and different forcing factors due to spatial sub-grid heterogeneity of soil properties and vegetation, leading to large differences from in situ soil moisture observations. Temporal coverage is generally good in both methods, but accuracy can vary based on the model inputs and assumptions.

Comparison.Question: In what ways do reanalysis products for soil moisture differ from in situ data in terms of depth and accuracy?
Comparison.Answer: Reanalysis products can provide soil moisture data at deeper soil depths than satellite observations and offer good temporal variations by assimilating observations into land surface models or Earth system models. However, they often exhibit higher disagreement with in situ soil moisture observations when the assimilated meteorological variables are biased, whereas in situ data provide more accurate direct measurements but are limited to specific locations and depths.

Interpretation.Question: How can machine learning techniques be leveraged to infer soil moisture patterns from diverse environmental variables such as land cover type, topography, and soil properties?
Interpretation.Answer: Machine learning techniques, like random forest, can be used to predict soil moisture by utilizing environmental variables such as land cover type, topography, and soil properties. These variables serve as predictors in the model, which is trained using in situ measurements of soil moisture. This approach allows for the creation of a high-resolution dataset that captures the spatial-temporal patterns of soil moisture across different regions.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges might arise from using in situ observations as benchmarks for developing high-resolution soil moisture datasets, and how can these challenges be addressed?
Interpretation.Answer: Challenges in using in situ observations as benchmarks include sparse station distribution, which may not adequately capture spatial coverage, and financial constraints that limit the number of stations. These challenges can be addressed by incorporating machine learning techniques that integrate additional data sources, such as satellite observations and reanalysis products, to enhance spatial resolution and coverage.

Interpretation.Question: What insights can be drawn from the spatial and temporal evaluation experiments about the accuracy and applicability of soil moisture datasets in different climatic regions?
Interpretation.Answer: The spatial and temporal evaluation experiments demonstrate that soil moisture datasets can achieve high accuracy when benchmarked against in situ data. These datasets, especially those validated through year-to-year and station-to-station experiments, are applicable for studying spatial-temporal patterns in various climatic regions, providing valuable insights for hydrological, meteorological, and ecological analysis.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes high errors in soil moisture estimation, particularly in the North China Monsoon Region?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The high errors in soil moisture estimation are often located in the North China Monsoon Region due to the complex spatiotemporal variations of soil moisture influenced by the inherent heterogeneity of soils, land cover, and weather.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why are in situ soil moisture observations considered to have lower errors compared to other data collection methods?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: In situ soil moisture observations are considered to have lower errors because they involve direct measurements using the probe measurement method, which typically results in more accurate data compared to satellite observations, land surface model simulations, Earth system model simulations, and reanalysis products.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the challenges of acquiring high-quality soil moisture data?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The challenges of acquiring high-quality soil moisture data arise from the complicated spatiotemporal variations of soil moisture, the spatial sub-grid heterogeneity of soil properties and vegetation, and the financial constraints that limit the density of field stations necessary for capturing adequate spatial coverage.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential outcomes of using machine learning techniques, such as random forest, in the data collection process for soil moisture datasets?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Machine learning techniques like random forest can lead to more accurate soil moisture predictions by utilizing in situ measurements and a variety of predictors such as ERA5-Land time series, leaf area index, land cover type, topography, and soil properties. This approach can create a high-resolution, long-term dataset with a seamless spatial distribution and low errors, making it a valuable complement to existing model-based and satellite-based datasets.

Causal Consequence.Question: How does the reliance on in situ soil moisture observations impact the quality and applicability of datasets developed for hydrological, meteorological, and ecological analyses?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Reliance on in situ soil moisture observations generally results in datasets that have lower errors compared to those derived from satellite observations, land surface model simulations, and reanalysis products. This high accuracy in estimation ensures that such datasets are applicable for studying spatial-temporal patterns, making them useful for hydrological, meteorological, and ecological analyses and models.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the consequences of integrating multiple data sources, such as ERA5-Land meteorological data and land cover types, in improving the spatial resolution of soil moisture datasets?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Integrating multiple data sources like ERA5-Land meteorological data, land cover types, topography, and soil properties can enhance the spatial resolution and quality of soil moisture datasets. This integration allows for a better representation of the inherent heterogeneity of soils and land cover, leading to more accurate and seamless spatial distributions, which are crucial for detailed hydrological and ecological modeling.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are employed to integrate multiple data sources, such as in situ observations and satellite data, for developing a high-resolution soil moisture dataset?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: For developing a high-resolution soil moisture dataset, procedures involve using in situ soil moisture observations as a benchmark, and integrating data from sources like ERA5-Land meteorological data, leaf area index, land cover type, topography, and soil properties as covariates. Machine learning, specifically the Random Forest approach, is used to train the model with these integrated data sources.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can machine learning techniques be utilized to enhance the accuracy of soil moisture estimation in regions with sparse in situ observations?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Machine learning techniques, such as Random Forest, are utilized to enhance soil moisture estimation accuracy by predicting soil moisture using available covariates, even in regions with sparse in situ observations. This method leverages the relationship between the input covariates and the soil moisture observed at available stations to generalize and predict moisture levels at unsampled locations.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What experimental procedures are conducted to validate the accuracy of long-term soil moisture datasets derived from machine learning models?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To validate the accuracy of long-term soil moisture datasets derived from machine learning models, two types of experiments are conducted: year-to-year and station-to-station experiments. These experiments compare the predicted soil moisture values against observed values from in situ measurements to assess the model's predictive accuracy across different temporal and spatial scales.

Enablement.Question: What machine learning techniques enable the derivation of high-resolution soil moisture datasets from in situ measurements?
Enablement.Answer: Random forest is used as a robust machine learning approach to predict soil moisture using ERA5-Land time series, leaf area index, land cover type, topography, and soil properties as predictors.

Enablement.Question: How do in situ observations enable lower error rates in soil moisture data collection compared to other methods?
Enablement.Answer: In situ soil moisture data, measured by the probe measurement method, lead to lower errors than satellite observations, land surface model simulations, Earth system model simulations, and reanalysis products because they are direct observations. However, their spatial coverage is limited due to financial constraints and station sparseness.

Enablement.Question: What conditions or resources enable the collection of soil moisture data over multiple soil layers and seamless spatial distribution?
Enablement.Answer: Offline land surface model simulations and Earth system model simulations enable the collection of soil moisture data that span multiple soil layers and have a seamless spatial distribution. However, these methods are subject to uncertainties due to the spatial sub-grid heterogeneity of soil properties and vegetation, leading to large differences from in situ SM observations.

Expectation.Question: Why might a dataset using in situ soil moisture observations face challenges in achieving comprehensive spatial coverage across different regions?
Expectation.Answer: A dataset using in situ soil moisture observations might face challenges in achieving comprehensive spatial coverage due to financial constraints and the sparse distribution of field stations, which may not capture adequate spatial coverage in many regions.

Expectation.Question: What are the expected reasons for high errors in soil moisture predictions specifically in regions like the North China Monsoon Region?
Expectation.Answer: High errors in soil moisture predictions in regions like the North China Monsoon Region are often expected due to the inherent spatiotemporal variations of soil moisture affected by the heterogeneity of soils, land cover, and weather conditions.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the effectiveness of using machine learning techniques in generating high-resolution soil moisture datasets?
Judgmental.Answer: The use of machine learning, particularly the random forest approach, is considered robust for predicting soil moisture by utilizing various predictors such as ERA5-Land time series, leaf area index, land cover type, topography, and soil properties. This approach appears effective in creating high-resolution datasets like SMCI1.0, which has shown strong accuracy compared to other soil moisture products.

Judgmental.Question: What are the potential challenges in relying on in situ data as the benchmark for soil moisture dataset development?
Judgmental.Answer: While in situ observations generally lead to lower errors compared to satellite and model simulations, they are often limited by sparse distribution and financial constraints, resulting in inadequate spatial coverage. Additionally, high errors are commonly found in regions like the North China Monsoon Region, posing challenges in capturing accurate measurements.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how machine learning can effectively predict soil moisture across different depths and regions.
Assertion.Answer: Machine learning, specifically using a random forest approach, can effectively predict soil moisture by leveraging in situ measurements as training data and incorporating various covariates like ERA5-Land time series, leaf area index, land cover type, topography, and soil properties, which help to model the complex spatial and temporal variations of soil moisture.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure why there are high errors in soil moisture measurements in the North China Monsoon Region.
Assertion.Answer: High errors in soil moisture measurements in the North China Monsoon Region may be due to the complex spatiotemporal variations of soil moisture influenced by the region's monsoon climate, which affects soil properties, land cover, and weather patterns, posing challenges to achieving accurate predictions.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how in situ observations differ from satellite-based soil moisture data in terms of spatial and temporal coverage.
Assertion.Answer: In situ observations provide direct and often more accurate soil moisture measurements but are limited by sparse spatial coverage due to financial constraints and station distribution, whereas satellite-based data offer global coverage with uniform distribution but are restricted to top-layer soil moisture and face limitations in regions with dense vegetation and snow or frozen soils.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify potential strategies to improve the accuracy and coverage of soil moisture datasets, particularly in regions with sparse field stations.
Request/Directive.Answer: Potential strategies to improve the accuracy and coverage of soil moisture datasets include leveraging machine learning models trained on a combination of in situ measurements and other predictors like meteorological data, leaf area index, and land cover type. Additionally, increasing the density of observational stations and utilizing satellite and reanalysis data can help address gaps in regions with sparse field stations.
